Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: Management closely monitors break logs because the phone queue remains consistently full.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story:
I glance at the clock on my monitor—my break is scheduled in two minutes, but the phone queue is still packed. Management has been strict lately, tracking every second we’re away from our desks. I know if I leave even a minute early, it’ll be flagged. But today is different. I’m not just a telemarketer; I’m also a voter, and I’ve arranged my break to drop off my mail-in ballot at the polling station down the street. 

When I finally get there, the poll worker inspects my envelope and frowns. “This signature is smudged. Please re-sign so your vote counts.” She’s polite but firm, and I know the rules—if I don’t comply, my ballot might be tossed. But my break is almost over, and if I’m late, I’ll get written up at work. My heart pounds as I stare at the pen she offers, torn between the demands of my job and my duty as a citizen.
